01.name: The Soil Science Experiment
steps: Collect Soil Samples: Dig small samples from different areas of your garden to get a representative sample.
Test Soil pH: Use a soil pH test kit to measure the acidity or alkalinity of your soil.
Analyze the Texture: Take a small amount of soil, moisten it, and try squeezing it into a ball. If it falls apart, it's sandy; if it holds, itâ€™s clayey or loamy.
Amend the Soil: Depending on the pH and texture, add compost, peat moss, or lime to adjust the soil quality.
Test Again: After a few weeks, retest the soil to track improvements.
tips: Use organic compost to enrich your soil and improve drainage.
Soil testing kits are inexpensive and easy to use, making it simple to adjust your soil as needed.
Adding mulch on top of soil can help retain moisture and reduce weeds.

02.name: The Seed Starter
02.description: In this quest, you'll start your gardening journey by planting seeds indoors and nurturing them until they sprout. This is the first step in creating a thriving garden, and it's an essential skill to learn as a beginner gardener.
steps: Choose Your Seeds: Pick a few easy-to-grow plants like herbs (basil, parsley), flowers (sunflowers, marigolds), or vegetables (tomatoes, lettuce).
Prepare Your Containers: Get small pots or seed trays. Fill them with a light, well-draining potting mix.
Plant the Seeds: Follow the seed packet instructions for depth and spacing. Gently press the seeds into the soil.
Water Gently: Water the seeds lightly, keeping the soil moist but not soaking. Use a spray bottle for even moisture distribution.
Find the Right Spot: Place the containers in a warm, sunny area to encourage germination.
Monitor Growth: Watch for your seeds to sprout, and keep an eye on their moisture levels
tips: Keep the soil moist but not soggy to avoid root rot.
If possible, use a humidity dome or plastic wrap to keep the moisture in.
Label your pots so you know what's planted where.

03.name: The Herb Garden Hero
03.description: Herb gardens are perfect for novice gardeners because they're low-maintenance and can thrive in small spaces. In this quest, you'll plant and care for a small herb garden to spice up your cooking and your garden.
steps: Choose Your Herbs: Pick herbs like basil, mint, thyme, or rosemary. These are easy to grow and useful in cooking.
Select a Location: Herbs need at least 6 hours of sunlight a day, so choose a sunny spot, such as a windowsill or a small outdoor garden.
Prepare the Soil: Use well-draining soil in containers or raised beds. Herbs don't like to sit in water, so make sure the containers have drainage holes.
Plant the Herbs: Space the herbs according to the instructions on the seed packets or tags. Don't overcrowd them.
Water and Maintain: Water the herbs regularly but allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Trim leaves as needed to promote growth.
tips: Keep herbs in a sunny spot and avoid overwatering, which can lead to root rot.
Some herbs, like mint, are invasive, so plant them in containers to prevent them from taking over your garden.
Regularly harvest herbs to encourage new growth and prevent them from flowering too early.
